title: What is the Fmi chord called in this chord progression: C, Cmaj7, C7, F, FM, and C? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Fm (F minor) chord showing up in a C major progression is a result of modal mixture. That’s when you take a chord from a different mode (i.e. minor (also known as aeolian), dorian, mixolydian, etc) and substitute it into the original mode of the song. So, if you take the chords of a major scale and then the minor scale: Maj: I ii iii IV V vi viiº (Cmaj Dmin Emin Fmaj Gmaj Amin Bdim) Min: i iiº bIII iv v bVI bVII (Cmin Ddim Emaj Fmin Gmin Amaj Bmaj) So if we’re in major, we can play around with taking some chords from minor. The progression you gave takes something that would’ve been F F C (F repeated for clarity) which is all in major, and then trades one iteration of the IV chord for the minor version, making it F Fm C (IV, iv, I). There are other really common ones between minor and major, and I’ll write some of my favorites in the key of C for clarity C Dm7 G7 C → C Ddim7 G7 C (I ii7 V7 I → I iiº7(or halfDim) V7 I) C G Am → C G Ab (or rather, Abmaj9#11 if you’re into the jazzy shtuff like me) (I V vi → I V bVI) Phewf! Get all that? Just a little tidbit more. There are 5 other modes you can use to switch out chords. I won’t delve into all of them, but my favorite example is probably from the Phrygian mode….the bII chooorrddddd wwooooooo Maj: I ii iii IV V vi viiº (Cmaj Dmin Emin Fmaj Gmaj Amin Bdim) Phr: i bII III iv vº VI vii (Cmin Ddim Emaj Fmin Gmin Amaj Bmaj) C Dm7 → C Dbmaj7 :) Plenty of other resources out there if you’re interested in learning more in this realm!

This chord sequence minus the Cmaj7 is a common turnaround progression in twelve-bar blues. In jazz, you can keep the Cmaj7, but you’ve got to time at least one of your changes between the beats, or you are going to end the progression on an up beat, which won’t sound right, because you want to hit that last chord on a down beat to signal finality. The turnaround works because you have a descending chromatic walking line. The C note in the C chord walks to the B note in the Cmaj7 chord, which walks to the Bb note in the C7 chord, which walks to the A note in the F chord, which walks to the Ab note in the Fm Chord, which finally walks to the G note of the C chord. Now to answer your question, that Fm chord is merely the minor subdominant chord in the C major scale. In the key of C major, blues and jazz artists would mix in notes of the parallel C minor scale and call them blue notes. That Ab in the Fm chord is the sixth note in the C minor scale. This added chromaticity (coloring) adds a distinctive spice to the notes, but as Duke Ellington once said, “It don’t mean a thing if it ain’t got that swing.”

Interesting question. If you look at what you've got there, you will find it's produced by a descending chromatic line from C to G. The CM7 really has no existence, just the C7 to F. Likewise the Fm. It sounds nice because it is a substitute for a dominant 7 b9 …. G7b9, which makes theoretical sense. These kinds of progressions are best suited for ending a song. If you're making them the main body, it's probably a lousy song.

“Called”? Are you looking for a pronunciation, or an analysis? It’s pronounced “Eff minor” and it’s usually written with a lower-case “m” instead of an upper-case “M”, like Fm. In terms of analysis, it’s the IVm chord in the key of C major (some write iv in lower case to indicate minor quality.)

I would speculate the FM chord is F minor. Minor chords are labelled with a lower case m to denote it is minor. Major chords are capitalized. Lower case chords are minor chords as well. Being both capitalized FM is confusing. Either way I still feel that FM is a minor chord.
It's the minor 4. F is the 4th note in C Major. Major 4 to minor 4 to 1 is a common pop progression. A is the 4th note in E Major so in the key of E this progression would be E, Emaj7, E7, A, Am, E.
